case_vignette: A 42-year-old man presents with a four-day history of experiencing headache, malaise, and stabbing right-sided headache. Two days after his initial symptoms appeared, he developed a rash over the area of pain. He reports that he went hiking through the Texas hill country prior to becoming ill. The patient is otherwise in good health and has an unremarkable medical history. Physical examination reveals unilateral erythematous, thin, raised plaques over the right forehead. In addition, he has no relevant social or family history.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

trial_0.vignette_frq: The final diagnosis is likely shingles (herpes zoster).

I have been experiencing headache, general feeling of discomfort or unease, and stabbing pain on the right side of my head. Two days after these started, I also developed a rash over the area where I feel the pain.

I noticed that the rash has developed into red, thin, raised patches on my right forehead.

No, I'm in good health and have an unremarkable medical history.
Has anyone in your family experienced similar symptoms or been diagnosed with a skin-related illness?
No, there is no relevant family history related to skin-related illnesses or similar symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Herpes Zoster (Shingles)
